former_owner_as_recorded: Obtained before December 1881 by Hamilton Cole (Grolier member, 1884-89) ; his sale (New York, 7 April 1890 n. 31, pl.), bought by Edward Bement (Grolier member, 1884-1931) who bequeathed it to the Grolier Club in 1932.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, 1881, in red crushed levant morocco by William Matthews (bookbinder in Brooklyn, NY and Grolier Club member, 1884-96) for Hamilton Cole; covers of both volumes tooled in gilt to the design by Le Gascon on a Plantin bible of the Marquis d'Adda.|Figurative details, ff. 1-303v; ff. 1-351v: 82 historiated initials (with two probably missing on the leaves that would have begun Exodus and Leviticus).|Layout, ff. 1-303v; ff. 1-351v: Gatherings apparently of 24 leaves (the psalter not on a separate quire); 2 columns of 46 lines.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1289.|ff. 1-303v; ff. 1-351v: Latin.|ff. 1-303v; ff. 1-351v: In the usual order for thirteenth century French bibles, and with the usual texts (but adding the prayer of Solomon to the end of Ecclesiasticus, and the Nicene Creed to the end of the Psalms). The expected set of 64 prologues is expanded to 68.

former_owner_as_recorded: Printed book given in 1840 to St. Peter's in Erfurt; George Bruce collection; given to the Grolier Club in July 1894 by David Wolfe Bruce.
note: Manuscript note: This manuscript no longer held by The Grolier Club.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1289.|ff. 1-2: Front pastedown in S. Gregorius Magnus, Moralia in Job (Cologne: C. Winters, n.d); Hain n. 7927.|ff. 1-2: Latin.|ff. 3-4: Back pastedown in S. Gregorius Magnus, Moralia in Job (Cologne: C. Winters, n.d); Hain n. 7927.|ff. 3-4: Latin.

former_owner_as_recorded: Belonged ca. 1870 to John Milne Buckie.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in English brown calf, ca. 1700.

former_owner_as_recorded: Herschel V. Jones collection, Minneapolis; his sale (New York, 23 January 1923, n. 124) to J. F. Drake; bequeathed to the Grolier Club by Beverly Chew.
physical_description: Binding: Cased in a later embossed silver binding.

former_owner_as_recorded: Gift to the Grolier Club by Miss Ellen King.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in original wooden boards covered with stamped leather and metal ornaments.
note: Manuscript note: This manuscript no longer held by The Grolier Club.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|ff. 1-139v: Latin.

former_owner_as_recorded: Given to the Grolier Club in 1931 by Charles Bain Hoyt.
physical_description: Binding: Framed.|Music, f. 1r-v: Square black notation on 4-line red staves.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|f. 1r-v: Latin.|f. 1r-v: Contains antiphons for the second nocturn at matins for the feast of St. Louis of Toulouse (19 August).

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Paris
artist_as_recorded: Master of the Brotherhood of Ste. Catherine
former_owner_as_recorded: Traces of a library stamp on f. 1. Acquired from Robson and Kerslake (according to de Ricci) by Daniel B. Fearing of Newport, Rhode Island who gave it to the Grolier Club in 1908.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in modern black morocco with gilt arabesque designs by Riviere and Son, 1889; spine gilt in 6 panels; edges gilt.|Figurative details, ff. 1-154v: 13 half-page miniatures in arched frames.|Script, ff. 1-154v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-154v: 19 gatherings mainly of 8 leaves; 16 long lines (17 long lines in the calendar).
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|ff. 1-154v: Artist of the Annunciation with some similarties to the Master of Thomas Hoo; secondary artist provisionally named as above from The Hague, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, MS 76 E 18; both artists in the tradition of the Boucicaut Master and the Bedford Master.|ff. 1-154v: Latin.|ff. 1-154v: Full calendar in French; gospel pericopes; Obsecro te & O intemerata (masc. forms); Hours of the BVM; Penitential psalms & litany; Short hours of the Cross and of the Holy Spirit; Office of the dead; prayers in French (Sonet 458, 504, 1876).
acknowledgments: This description is based on the extensive work of Prof. James Marrow.|ff. 1-154v: We thank Prof. James Marrow for naming the artist, and for his collaboration with Francois Avril in identifying parallel manuscripts.

former_owner_as_recorded: George Bruce collection; given to the Grolier Club in July 1894 by David Wolfe Bruce.
physical_description: Binding: Bound in French calf, s. XVII.|Figurative details, ff. 1-160v: 7 miniatures.
note: Manuscript note: This manuscript no longer held by The Grolier Club.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|ff. 1-160v: Latin.

former_owner_as_recorded: The Earl of Hopetoun sale (London, 1889, n. 402) to Matthews. Given to the Grolier Club in 1905 by Daniel B. Fearing.
physical_description: Binding: Original wooden boards and brown velvet, rebacked.|Figurative details, ff. 1-107v: 4 miniatures remain (at least 5 or possibly as many as 7 miniatures are cut away).|Script, ff. 1-107v: Gothic.|Layout, ff. 1-107v: 16 long lines.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|ff. 1-107v: Conservation, September 2005, by Mindy Dubansky.|ff. 1-107v: Latin.|ff. 1-107v: Calendar in French; Short Hours of the Cross and of the Holy Spirit; Suffrages; Hours of the Virgin; Penitential psalms and litany; Office of the Dead (3 lessons only, whose resp. are: Credo quod, Qui lazarum, Libera me domine de morte eterna).

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rouen
former_owner_as_recorded: Arms of first owners: 1, azure a six-pointed star or between three crescents or; 2, gules a bend sable charged with three small cups (?) or. George Bruce collection; given to the Grolier Club in July 1894 by David Wolfe Bruce.
physical_description: Binding: Modern red velvet.|Figurative details, ff. 1-71v: 15 miniatures; 22 smaller miniatures in the calendar.|Script, ff. 1-71v: Bâtarde.|Layout, ff. 1-71v: 2 columns of 28 lines.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1290.|ff. 1-71v: Latin.|ff. 1-71v: Calendar in French; gospel pericopes; Obsecro te & O Intemerata (masc. forms), other prayers; Short Hours of the Holy Spirit (misbound); Hours of the Virgin; Short Hours of the Cross; Penitential psalms; Office of the Dead; prayers and suffrages.

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rome
former_owner_as_recorded: Arms: 1, azure a fesse argent between three wheels argent; 2, argent a crescent azure and in chief a label of three points gules. Henry W. Poor sale (New York, 17 November 1908, I, n. 800) to G. D. Smith. Bequest to the Grolier Club by Beverly Chew.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVIII, in Italian embossed silver binding with two fore edge clasps.|Figurative details, ff. 1-241v: Miniature; historiated initials.|Script, ff. 1-241v: Rounded gothic book hand.|Layout, ff. 1-241v: 14 long lines.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1291.|ff. 1-241v: A leaf missing between the present ff. 49 and 50.|ff. 1-241v: Latin.|ff. 1-241v: Calendar (incl. Geminianus, Zenobius, Reparata, Cerbonus, Ansanus); Hours of the BVM; Penitential psalms and litany (incl. Zenobius and Reparata); Office of the Dead; Short Hours of the Cross; Hours of the Passion; Short Hours of the Holy Spirit; prayers.

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rome
former_owner_as_recorded: Arms of the first owner: or three gateways with two turrets gules, with the initials A.P.; Samuel Putnam Avery collection; exhibited at the Grolier Club in 1892, n. 97; given to the Grolier Club in 1918 by Samuel Putnam Avery, Jr.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVIII, in Italian embossed silver binding with arms (a hand holding a scythe) and the initials, ADIU.|Figurative details, ff. 1-164v: 1 miniature; 14 historiated initials.|Script, ff. 1-164v: Rounded gothic book hand.|Layout, ff. 1-164v: 13 long lines.

title_as_recorded: Moralia in Job|Summary of the Moralia in Job
former_owner_as_recorded: From the collection of the Abate Matteo Luigi Canonici (1727-1806), purchased in 1835 by Rev. Walter Sneyd (1810?-1888); his sale, London, 1903, n. 344 to Quaritch; given to the Grolier Club in 1912 by Archer M. Huntington (Grolier member, 1894-1955).
physical_description: Binding: Bound, ca. 1840, in English brown stamped calf in a design with a rectangular central panel infilled with six long strips of twirled floral sprays.|Other decoration, ff. 1-213v: Of the 37 major initials expected for the 35 books of the Moralia, and its dedication and prologue, only 23 are present; the 14 initials for books 10-12, 17-18, 20-25, 27, 30 and 35 are missing due to loss of leaves.|Number of scribes, ff. 1-213v: Several.|Layout, ff. 1-213v: Gatherings mainly of 8 leaves but many gatherings and leaves are missing; 2 columns of 55 lines ruled in dry point up to f. 160 (quire break) and thereafter in lead; pricking along both inner and outer margins; written above top line.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1291.|ff. 1-213v: Latin.|f. 1 blank; ff. 1v-213: Missing leaves with consequent loss of text in at least 7 points after ff. 90v, 130v, 141v, 144v, 152v, 168v, 208v.|f. 213v: Summary of the amount of the text of Job covered by each book of Gregory's Moralia, added in a contemporary hand.|Explicit, f. 213v: In primo libro vir erat in terra hus usque sicut faciebat.

title_as_recorded: De duobus amantibus|De miseriis curialium|Invectiva ad indivum et detractorem|Sequitur invective Alani ad invidum et detractorem|Epistula ad Raymundum
author_as_recorded: Pius II|Alain Chartier|Pseudo Bernard of Clairvaux
former_owner_as_recorded: Arms of first owner: azure a flame gules and or accompanied in chief by an inverted crescent argent. Owned by the Earl of Hopetoun (his sale, London, 1889, n. 110) to Matthews for Daniel B. Fearing, who gave it to the Grolier Club in 1908.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1291. Kristeller, Iter italicum vol. 5, p. 317.|ff. 1-93v: Irregular foliation.|ff. 1-93v: Latin.|Explicit, f. 88r-v: //licitam fore vitam.|Explicit, ff. 88v-90: Maledicta tua molestie tulissem emulator acerrime.

title_as_recorded: Histoire de la mort de Henri IV|Missal
former_owner_as_recorded: Gift in January 1898 by Samuel Putnam Avery.
physical_description: Binding: Old vellum binding with leaves from another manuscript (see Pt. 2).
note: Manuscript note: This manuscript no longer held by The Grolier Club.|Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1291.|ff. 1-141v: Latin.|xx: Latin.|ff. 1-141v: Copied from the edition printed in Paris in 1611.

title_as_recorded: Excerpts regarding Josephus and Eusebius of Caesarea|Contra Appionem|Historia ecclesiastica
former_owner_as_recorded: On back flyleaf, "Emptus est iste liber pro septem florenis anno domini M CCCC lxx per Iohannem abbatem," of St. Mang, O.S.B. in Füssen; at secularization, the library went to the Oettingen-Wallerstein collection. Owned by Norman H. Strouse.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVI, in tawed, cream-colored pigskin over boards, with stamps of rosettes, flowers in ovals and triangles, a dragon in a rectangle, fleurs-de-lis, and rolls of foliage and scrollwork with brass metalwork; clasps.|Script, ff. 1-145v: Bastarda.|Layout, ff. 1-145v: Gatherings mostly of 12 leaves, of paper with parchment for the outer and inner bifolia; 2 columns of 40 lines.
note: Manuscript note: Bound with a printed edition of Flavius Josephus, De antiquitate Judaicaand De bello Judaico Augsburg: Johannes Schüssler, 1470 [HC* 9451; P* 1589; BMC II 327], itself of 288 leaves.|Bibliography: Kristeller, Iter italicum vol. 5 p. 317 under the call number, 34.1/Augsburg/Schuessler/1470/Folio.|ff. 1-145v: On f. 145v, Conscripta est hec presens hystoria In monasterio sancti magni in faucibus sub regimine . . . Iohannis cognomento Hessen pro tunc prefati monasterii abbatis per fratrem conradum werdensem Sub anno . . . 1462 feria sexta ante Invocavit.|ff. 1-145v: Latin.|Verso + facing recto: Notes from Bk. 1 and Bk. 2 added to the last page of the printed text and on the facing added leaf, by the same person who compiled the bibliographic excerpts from Jerome on the front pastedown.|Explicit, Verso + facing recto: Denique de bello quod apud nost contigit nuper quidam hystorias scribentes ediderunt.

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rome
former_owner_as_recorded: Comte de Rochechouart arms on ff. 1, 84; Castel-Lodève arms on f. 2. Frederick Perkins of Chipstead, Kent to Bennett; Simon J. Schwartz of New Orleans to G. D. Smith; Smith sale to G. Wells; Waters S. Davis by whose children it was given to the Grolier.
physical_description: Binding: Bound, s. XVIII (?), in dark green morocco with gilt tooled floral design on both covers; spine and turn-ins gilt; rose watered silk doublures and endleaves; edges gilt.|Figurative details, ff. 1-85v: 11 half-page miniatures; some historiated initials; f. 34 (lauds) with Baptism of Christ missing.|Script, ff. 1-85v: Humanistic.|Layout, ff. 1-85v: Gatherings mainly of 8 leaves; 20 long lines ruled in red.
note: Bibliography: De Ricci, p. 1668 (when it was in the collection of Waters S. Davis, 1150 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY; d. 12 February 1940, according to an obituary notice in the journal, Speculum).|ff. 1-85v: Five miniatures excised from the ms sometime after 1937 (description by de Ricci) of which 4 were noticed at Sotheby's, NY in 1996 in the estate of Fr. Redmond Ambrose Burke, C.S.V. (1914-1996) and returned to the Grolier; f. 34 still missing.|ff. 1-85v: Latin.|ff. 1-85v: Full calendar; gospel pericopes; passion according to John; Hours of the BVM (lacks f. 34, Lauds); suffrages; Obsecro te (masc. forms); prayers in French; added notes in Latin. MS may be fragment: lacks penitential psalms, litany, office of the dead, etc.
acknowledgments: This description is based on the extensive work of Prof. James Marrow.|ff. 1-85v: We are grateful to Prof. James Marrow and Paul Needham who recognized the excised leaves from this and other manuscripts and saw to their return.

title_as_recorded: Chy commenchent les eures de la crois|Book of Hours
former_owner_as_recorded: Discovered in the Grolier Club's files, September 2009.
physical_description: Binding: Not bound.|Other decoration, f. 1r-v: 7-line painted initial on square gold ground; 2- and 1-line initials in gold on white-patterned alternating rose or blue grounds with the other color as infilling; gold and colors bar border in the outer and lower margins with acanthus/flower sprays.|Script, f. 1r-v: Gothic.|Layout, f. 1r-v: 16 long lines.
note: f. 1r-v: Copied ca. 1460s.|f. 1r-v: Latin.|f. 1r-v: Contains the opening of the Short Hours of the Cross.|Incipit, f. 1r-v: et misericordiam fidelibus defunctis.|Explicit, f. 1r-v: Domine labia mea aperies.
